etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in The Century Dictionary. From onlay

definitions: An item of cloth, paper, etc., fixed on the surface of something, especially for decorative effect; a thin piece of leather, etc., mounted on the cover of a book for ornamentation.
An occlusal rest extended so as to cover the whole occlusal surface of a tooth.

etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in Old English Martyrology. From on- + lay

definitions: To lay on (literal and figurative): see to lay on.
